The Civil Service Retirement System and Federal Employees' Retirement System are amended to allow FBI employees to retire at 65 instead of 60 years of age. The authority for exemptions will end after December 31, 2009. The Civil Service Retirement System and Federal Employees' Retirement System have been amended to allow FBI employees to retire at 65 instead of 60 years of age, with exemptions ending after December 31, 2009. SEC. 2. RETENTION AND RELOCATION BONUSES. Sec. 5759 of title 5, United States Code allows the Director of the FBI to pay retention and relocation bonuses to employees with unique qualifications or essential services to prevent them from leaving federal service. Payment of a bonus under Sec. 5759 of title 5, United States Code is contingent upon the employee entering into a written service agreement with the Bureau to complete a period of service. The bonus may not exceed 50 percent of the employee's basic pay and can be granted for a different position or geographic area with a higher cost of living. The authority to grant retention bonuses under Sec. 5759 of title 5, United States Code will cease after December 31, 2009. SEC. 3. FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION RESERVE SERVICE. Amends Chapter 35 of title 5, United States Code to allow retention of retired specialized employees at the FBI. The Director of the FBI may establish a Reserve Service for temporary reemployment of former full-time employees during emergencies. Retired annuitants can be reemployed without impacting their annuity. Membership is limited to ex-Bureau employees. The FBI Reserve Service allows reemployment of former full-time employees during emergencies without impacting personnel ceilings. Members may receive transportation and per diem for training.
